author: Russell Brandom
title: Facebook contractors threaten to stop work over missing paychecks
description: Contractors at an Accenture site in Austin that handles moderation and other services for Meta and WhatsApp are still waiting for their holiday paychecks and threatening to stop work as a result.

author: Os Keyes
title: It Doesn't Make Sense to Treat Facebook Like a Public Utility
description: It's an American solution to a global problem.

author: https://www.facebook.com/bbcnews
title: France fines Google and Facebook over cookies
description: French regulators have fined Google and Facebook for violating EU privacy rules.

author: Adi Robertson
title: Meta reportedly canceled a 300-person VR / AR operating system project
description: Meta, formerly known as Facebook, has reportedly canceled a VR / AR operating system known as XROS after the departure of project head Mark Lucovsky.

author: Russell Brandom
title: Mark Zuckerberg and Sundar Pichai were involved in ad collusion plot, claims court filing
description: A new complaint in the antitrust case led by Texas AG Ken Paxton alleges that Google and Facebook colluded to dominate programmatic advertising in a deal overseen by the company’s respective CEOs.

title: WhatsApp inches forward on bringing Reactions to its app

author: Cecilia Kang
title: A Facebook antitrust suit can move forward, a judge says, in a win for the F.T.C.
description: The government can proceed with its claims that the company abused its monopoly power through acquisitions.

author: Caitlin McGarry
title: Now You Can Pay Money to Use Instagram
description: Popular Instagrammers can now start charging you money to view their content, in a move that seemed pre-ordained from the moment that Facebook (now calling itself Meta) acquired the photo-sharing app. Read more...

title: Tracking Facebook connections between parent groups and vaccine misinfo
description: Tracking connections pre and post COVID also shows the pull of conspiracy groups.

author: Emma Roth
title: Facebook’s plan to offer free internet in developing countries ended up costing users, WSJ reports
description: A report by the Wall Street Journal reveals users of Facebook’s free internet service, which the company deploys in developing nations, have been unknowingly getting charged.
